results.title: Rosalie Kunoth-Monks
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian biography”.
Rosalie Kunoth-Monks: Aboriginal activist, actor, social worker, Parliamentary Candidate 1979-1981, President Aboriginal Legal Aid NT 1983-87, 1990-93, was born in Utopia, Central Australia, 1937 and is of German Aboriginal parentage. Kunoth-Monks discusses her education at St Mary’s Children’s Hostel, Alice Springs, and on being discovered by Charles and Elsa Chauvel as the lead in “Jedda”. She talks about working on the film, and her family’s response to it, in particular the sexual references. A greater passion was to help people, and Rosalie joined the Community of the Holy Name in Melbourne and was a nun for ten years, also gaining training during this period in childcare. Working as an Aboriginal liaison officer in Victoria after leaving the sisterhood, Kunoth-Monks also established the first Aboriginal Family Group home, in addition to marrying during this period. A return to Central Australia saw her working for the Country Liberal Party and being active in social welfare before she returned, full circle, to Utopia.

results.title: Bruce Dawe
results.creator_credit: Linda Kruger, Robin Hughes, SBS-TV and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian biography”.
An intimate encounter with the extraordinary “poet of suburbia”, Bruce Dawe, whose ability to evoke the drama and beauty of everyday life has set him amongst the most accessible and highly regarded of Australian poets. His highly empathic style of writing stems from a staggered history of variant occupations, contact with those from a diversity of backgrounds and failed studies as he drifted through his early years with a skill for writing but little direction. Here his motivations and writing process as they have since stood are explored. He discusses his family history and early life, his fascinations and motivations and his view of his place in the poetry world of giving a voice to ordinary Australians. Through interviews with Dawe, footage of him reading his poetry and commentary on his life and writing this is a comprehensive personal insight into Bruce Dawe’s life and influences.

results.title: Graeme Bell
results.creator_credit: Frank Heimans, Sharon Connolly and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian biography”.
Often described as the ‘father of Australian jazz’ Graeme Bell has had a sixty year love affair with music, both as a performer and a composer. Discover the story of his life, speak to the man about his passion, and hear his wonderful music.

results.title: Highlands of New Guinea
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia today”.
Social and economic changes in the Western Highlands of Papua New Guinea as demonstrated in the construction of an airstrip at Lake Kopiagu and the first Mount Hagen Show. Credits include Stanley Hawes, Frank Bagnall, Maslyn William, Shan Benson, Dennis Hill and Robert Gibbs.

results.title: Water: our problem
results.creator_credit: Joe Scully, John Martin-Jones, Lee Robinson, Maslyn Williams and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia today”.
Illustrates our dependence on water and our inability to exist without it. Tells why Australia has water shortages and what is being done to irrigate the great inland tracts from mountainous regions of heavy snowfall and abundant rains. Australia has the largest artesian basin in the world, from which thousands of square miles have been made productive. Scientific progress has been made in the fields of rainmaking by chemical cloud dusting, and desalination of sea water.

results.title: Sir John Monash
results.creator_credit: Jennie Blackwood, John Martin-Jones, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, State Electricity Commission of Victoria and Zanthus Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia today”.
Reviews the life and work of the Australian scholar, lawyer, soldier and engineer, Sir John Monash. Shows his career as an engineer; a commander of troops in World War I; and his work as a Commissioner of the State Electricity Commission during the development of Yallourn. Edited by Jennie Blackwood; photographed by Adrian Bodington; sound by Alan Allen; introduction by John West.

results.title: Production unlimited
results.creator_credit: Robert Parker, R.V. Edwards and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia today”.
Surveys the rapid development of Australian secondary industries, more than doubling output since 1939, with particular reference to the light engineering field.
